characters: ON THE WALL OF THE SHAFT
QUAIL TRANSFORMS INTO A HIGHLY SKILLED KILLING MACHINE.
THIN AIR AND STAND THERE IN THE ROOM A FEW FEET AWAY FROM
BLACKNESS BROKEN BY PULSES OF WHITE LIGHT
HEAVES BENEATH HIM ... HUGE STONE BLOCKS CRASH DONW ON
PISTOL IS SUCKED, CLATTERING, OUT THE VENT
SHOCK, QUAIL SEES A MAN MANIFEST HIMSELF HIMSELF OUT OF
A TINY LITTLE HEAD GROWING OUT OF THE BACK OF HIS NECK
TO HER WRIST BY A CHAIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we can see, filling the entire frame is a flame-orang sky...almost like the sky from the burning of Atlanta in "Gone with the Wind". SUPERIMPOSE:  Presenter credit. PAN DOWN lower and lower until we see the terrain below.. the desert.  There is no vegetation whatever, just sand a odd-shaped rock formations.  The air is filled with red d which alternately obscures and then reveals the image. CAMERA MOVES FORWARD optically - enlarging the film grain the process.

dialogues.speaker: OPENING CREDITS BEGIN.
dialogues.text: ANOTHER SHOT of a barren landscape, once more with bizarr rocks.  Dust.  Sound of wind.  CAMERA MOVES FORWARD again DISSOLVE. ANOTHER LANDSCAPE, but this time, in the distance are som enormous plastic domes.  Sunlight striking them and refle ing causes brilliant rainbows.  CAMERA optically tracks toward the dome, seen in tantalizingly indistinct fashion through the red dust.  DISSOLVE... ANOTHER ANGLE, and, in the distance, on the horizon of th arid landscape is a huge SPHINX-LIKE STRUCTURE.  (It is reminiscent of the Egyptian sphinx, but both body and fac though gargoyle-like, are different in design.)  There ar some large pyramids not far from the sphinx.  CAMERA MOVE optically FORWARD.  DISSOLVE. CAMERA is much closer to the sphinx and is directly in fr It moves (combination of zoom and optical printer move) towards the eyes, which appear to be red gems. As CAMERA APPROACHES one of the eyes, it appears to be stained red glass, as in a temple.  Suddenly there is a terrific explosion and the glass shatters into millions o fragments which hurtle toward the camera...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN wearing a LIGHTWEIGHT THERMAL SUIT is RUNNING THROU THIS LABYRINTH of TUNNELS.  The GROUND TREMBLES under him as if in an earthquake.  We cannot clearly make out his f especially since he wears some kind of BREATHING APPARATU over a portion of it. The surface of the tunnel's "walls" is curious;  the wall are, again, bright reddish orange, and a composite of two different substances:  rough-textured, clay-like material and red quartz, which glistens like crystal. The man throws a backward glance over his shoulder, fear- fully, as he runs.  His HANDS are SPLATTERED with BLOOD. Because of this, the RED GLOW, the air of FEAR to the man and the GROUND HEAVING and BUCKLING, there is almost a SATANIC suggestion to the scene. Suddenly, up AHEAD of the man, there appears a BRILLIANT WHITE LIGHT.  He SEES IT, and runs even faster towards it We are ALMOST UP TO THE LIGHT, and we SEE HANDS REACHING OUT OF THE LIGHT TOWARDS US... that seem to beckon him to SAFETY. ABRUPTLY, the ENTIRE SCREEN GOES RED, BUT IN REVERSE NEGA with YELLOW LAYOVERS.  (So that all the images we see -- ENTIRE FRAME -- are small YELLOW AREAS diffused on a RED BACKGROUND.)  It is much like looking at a tableau made o of molten lava.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUGLAS QUAIL and his wife KRISTEN, are asleep in bed. Gradually the room lights BRIGHTEN.  The CLOCK CHIMES and begins SPEAKING in a soft, feminine voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Tick, tock, seven o'clock.  Time to rise and open your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't budge.  Shortly, the clock CHIMES again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Tick, tock, seven-oh-one.  Time to get up, the day had begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail's wife stirs.  Maddeningly, the clock CHIMES a thir time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Tick, tock --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail reaches out and shuts the clock off.  Then he sits in bed. He swings his legs out from under the covers and sits on edge of the bed.  He puts on his glasses and sits, lost thought. He is a good-looking but conventional man in his early thirties.  He seems rather in awe of his wife, who is attractive and rather off-hand towards him. Kirsten pulls on her robe, lights a cigarette, sits fishi for her slippers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dreamed about Mars again... it was bizarre, yet is was so real...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casual) It's your time of the month again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail looks at her quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; world-weary air) At least once a month.  Douglas Quail's obsession.  For twelve years you've been talking about Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People do go to Mars, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Douglas.  But not you.  Not us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail looks crestfallen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; disdainful) As it is, we can barely scrape by on your lousy ten thousand a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves the room.  He meditates on what she said, depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail and Kirsten sit at a small table, eating breakfast. On the WALL is projected the front page of a NEWSPAPER. Drinking his coffee, Quail studies the wall with the air of a man who had his "node stuck in a newspaper," ignorin his wife. The newspaper headline reads:  "RIOTING ON MARS OVER WATE

dialogues.speaker: TAX."
dialogues.text: His wife is reading a different article:  "Four Women Rap Man in Park."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) What do they expect ... the way men dress these days ... then they scream rape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is absorbed in his own paper and doesn't hear her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know -- let's really do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rape men in the park?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Go to Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (withering) Go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can pool our savings and I've got some sick leave coming, besides my regular vacation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting; corrects herself) ...more of a half-wit.  For a start a war could break out there any day ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gestures toward the TV screen where Martian police are keeping protesters behind a barrier.  Some have signs reading "A FREE MARS", "DOWN WITH COHAAGEN", "EARTH - OUT etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just media talk.  They're... (indicating the protesters) ...just a minority.  They're powerless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's a lot of things we need around here before we waste our money on a trip to Mars.  We're broke.  I'm just a slave around this dump. Now if you were capable of finding a better job....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen clock chimes and talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's now eight.  You'll be late!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be late!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps up quickly from the table, picks up his coat and briefcase, kisses KIRSTEN's perfunctorily offered cheek and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRACKS with Quail as he walks along the busy moder street towards a subway station.  Modern cars (out of foc pass noiselessly between the camera and Quail.  There is plaintive tune being played on violin.  Quail pauses and gives a wad of notes to the aged violinist, then walks on briskly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail enters the station.  Everybody must pass through a weapons check before proceeding to the platforms. TWO ARMED GUARDS stand at either side, as commuters pass through an electronic beam.  On a screen, the entire body of each person is seen in X-ray.  All of them are clearly carrying a gun in their inside coat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No weapon again, Mr. Quail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep forgetting, Herb.  They frighten me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  Well, it's the law, Mr. Quail.  Has been since 1990 they tell me.  Tomorrow - ya carry ya gun or ya get reported.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUARD gestures to his associate.  They've obviously been through this with Quail before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  Herb, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail walks on to the track area.  The train arrives. Signs above each approaching car say "CAR FULL", "ROOM FOR 10 PERSONS", etc.  Quail goes to a carriage marked "NEW CAR".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors open and the crowd surges on.  Quail grabs a seat.  At intervals throughout the car are VIDEO MONITORS on which a NEWS BROADCAST is showing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- more violence today from Mars's strike-torn ore colonies --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone ignores the broadcast -- except Quail, who perks instantly at the word "Mars." The NEWSCASTER is a young black man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...but Earth Intelligence Operations Director Vilos Cohaagen, clearly worried about the damage to Mars's all important tourist industry was today dismissive of the dissident groups....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV scene switches to a press conference.  COHAAGEN, sur- rounded by AIDES, steps in front of a podium packed with news network microphones and cameras.  Cohaagen is a striking, intense man with an obvious air of power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're dealing with a bunch of extremists and unrepresentative lunatics.  Mars is a happy and prosperous protectorate of Earth... and will remain so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train stops at another station and more people pile o Quail tries to watch the broadcast through the bodies passing in front of him and intermittently blocking the image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There have been some criticisms, sir....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no further comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news conference ends and a bright looking young man comes on the screen.  Quail continues to watch, though not as interested, initially, as he was by the Mars story Few of the other passengers bother looking at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, commuters.  This portion of your trip is brought to you by Rekall, Inc.  Do you have a dream that never came true?  Do you aspire - but only perspire?  Has the great adventure passed you by?  Then come to... REKALL, where what might have been will have been. For the memories of a lifetime... REKALL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail watches the commercial through to the end, but does seem to take it very seriously.  He glances away as a car comes on the screen with REKALL's numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is seated at a computer console in a vast beehive of a room.  Numerous people are typing information onto the screens.  Quail pauses in his typing, thoughtful.  He then types in a little more information, then pauses agai On the screen, a sentence types itself... WHY HAVE YOU STOPPED?  REQUEST MORE INFORMATION. Quail read it and continues. 9       INT. McCLANE'S OFFICE - REKALL - DAY Scene opens on a CU of McCLANE, a genial, bubbling, enthu iastic man. McCLANE We're all dreamers, Douglas. But here at Rekall, dreams are our business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses a button on his desk and the chairs on which they are seated appear to be in outer space.  Countless stars glitter all around.  Startlingly, a comet whizzes b Quail is amazed.  McClane grins and presses the button again.  The scene changes to a beautiful underwater coral reef.  Multi-colored fish swim around the chairs and desk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... is the process really that effective?  A false memory!? McCLANE (shaking his head; smiling) We prefer the term "extra- factual implant".  Your memory will be complete in every way.  You will have gone to Mars.  We guarantee that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it in any way dangerous? I mean, the medical techniques? McCLANE Not when you deal with qualified operators - like us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses the button again and the normal office returns Quail looks around, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just - incredible. McCLANE And look at our follow-up program!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts items on the desk as he talks. McCLANE (continuing) Space-flight ticket stub... passport... vaccination certificates... matchbooks from Martian Nouvelle Cuisine Restaurants, souvenirs, post cards... even names of people you met - now back there - who you can call and discuss your trip with... by the way, we plant these things where you'll come across them at random in the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... I'll know I hired you. That'll destroy the whole illusion. McCLANE (smiling; self- satisfied) But you won't remember me, or having been here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't? McCLANE Your money back if you do! We've never paid out yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail slumps backs in his chair, overwhelmed. McCLANE (continuing) And we have a special this month, for only two-hundred thousand dollars more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the press of a button, a list appears on the wall...

dialogues.speaker: A17 INTELLIGENCE AGENT
dialogues.text: McCLANE (continuing) You can have a new identity for the duration of the trip. Pick one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail's eyes linger on "Intelligence Agent."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Intelligence Agent"... wouldn't that be dangerous?  I might attack.... McCLANE (airily) No.  No.  You're a retired agent.  Mars was your last mission and you're never to break your cover.  But you'll have got the girl, killed the baddies, and saved the Universe.  Not bad, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... about the whole thing... it's all such a fake.  I won't really have gone.  I won't really.... McCLANE (kind but firm) Let's face it, Douglas, you, and millions of people like you have no chance of ever getting to Mars and you'd never qualify as a secret agent for EIO.  This - REKALL - is the only way to achieve your dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and walks around to Quail's chair. McCLANE (continuing) Think about it, Douglas. Think, too, what a terrible boor a real holiday is. Lost tickets, endless arguments, lousy hotels, missed connections, rotten weather... Rekall will supply you with perfect, happy memories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is thoughtful, willing to be totally convinced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is sitting, distracted, in an uncomfortable modern chair.  Kirsten is watching a near-pornographic film on TV.  She casually lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that's illegal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  Who's going to report me?  You?... wimp....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches a torrid love scene on the video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Screwing around's illegal, too.  But just give me half a chance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail looks at her with distaste.  His expression changes to one of resolve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is stretched out on a plush reclining couch, alongs some strange-looking lab equipment, wearing a hospital-ty smock.  In the b.g. hovers a TECHNICIAN, adjusting some instrumentation (discreet banks of computers, etc.) -- th apparently relates to the lab equipment next to Quail.  T room in a dim, soothing booth, lit by indirect lighting. Quail looks a little concerned as he studies all the instrumentation next to him -- as one always does at the dentist's, looking at the drills. The door opens abruptly, in walks a cute-looking LITTLE OLD LADY, wearing a JOGGING SUIT.  (A RUTH GORDON-TYPE.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Doctor Sophie Lull. Sorry I'm late. (walks toward coat closet) I'll be right with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dons a white medical smock that covers her jogging suit, then slings on heavy, lead-lined protective vest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at instrument console) This really going to work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It the Pope Martian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lull's assistant, the TECHNICIAN in b.g., who had been steadily working on the instrumentation, now looks over at Lull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at machine) Okay -- that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Lull extends a long rubber tube, a hypodermic needle attached to it.  Quail eyes it warily.  She swabs the bac of his hand in preparation, notices his apprehension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, just relax, kid.  This ain't gonna hurt.  Just a controlled drip of Narkadine. When you're under, I'll just ask ya a few questions, nothin' real personal, just full details of yer private life so's we can tailor the wish-fulfillment program to your needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She injects the needle into his hand as she speaks, tapes it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) See?  Painless.  I didn't feel a thing.  Hey, you're a nice kid... you like a little somethin' extra?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail, embarrassed, starting to go under, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; pleased) Good!  Kid -- have I got a girl for you!  She's gonna like you.  You're good-lookin'. (beat) Gettin' sleepy? (he nods) Good.  Now, what's the first thing you think of when you're thinkin' about Mars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistfully) Well... I'd like to see the Martian Sphinx...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay -- you will, Dougle!  I want ya to start counting backwards from a hundred for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sleepily) One hundred... ninety-nine... ninety-eight... ninety-seven... ninety-six... ninety-five....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice drops off; his eyes close.  Lull studies him, adjusts some instruments, then turns to Ernie, glancing briefly at a typed sheet in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Ernie, the trip to Mars; number sixty-two... and throw in that blonde... We'll give him a real good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty-two... and... the blonde...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes two discs and inserts the first one into a machi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, is this one wild.  He won't want to come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie inserts the second disk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dougie?  This Sophie Lull. Can ya hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sophie....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! ... I'm gonna ask ya a few more questions now.  Ya think you'll be able to answer 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attaboy!  To begin with, I wanna ask ya; -- You sex life.  How many orgasms a week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11      INT. McCLANE'S OFFICE - DAY McClane has several file drawers open and is removing div objects and placing them on his desk. These items apparently are objects Rekall, Inc. intends to "plant" for some client of theirs to find (perhaps even Quail) -- as part of his fantasy. While he is putting these things on his desk, the PHONE BUZZES.  He answers it. McCLANE Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered; tense) Howie?  Listen, you'd better get in here. McCLANE (not too concerned) Not another schizoid embolism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) You'd better get in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McClane come quickly in, brushing the swinging door open. Lull and Ernie look up as he enters.  Quail lies on the couch, breathing slowly and regularly, his eyes closed. McClane looks queryingly at Lull, who motions him to silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bends over Quail) Quail?  Dougie, can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell McClane what you told us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McClane glances sharply at Lull, then turns to Quail. Quail's eyes open and scan the room.  They settle on McClane.  These eyes have changed:  they have become cold and steely.  In fact, Quail's entire personality seems to have changed -- his face has acquired a flint- edged hardness.  He is chillingly menacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a deadly voice) All of you in this room are dead. McCLANE (not quite taking it seriously) What's he talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've broken my cover. McCLANE What is this?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McClane's eyes flash angrily at Lull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Narkadine cracked a memory cap.  Mars -- (she's scared) He's really been there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a chilly silence in the room as McClane digests this. McCLANE Forced suppression?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With spontaneous breakthrough. McCLANE Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at Quail as if he's a ticking bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) You've compromised the Sphinx Project.  You'll have to be silenced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they're all panicked. McCLANE Wait a minute.  Quail --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name isn't Quail. McCLANE Listen... whoever you are... sir.... (almost pleading) ...This is all an accident. We'll destroy all the records. No one will know.  I swear it. Believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you, but that won't stop E.T.O. from killing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rekall people stare at each other in quiet horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Killing you... killing you... killing you....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice trails off, his eyes close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intensely) He wants a false memory implanted -- of a trip he really took. (pause) Someone at Earth Intelligence Operations erased his memory. All he know was going to Mars meant something special to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do?  Graft a false memory pattern over the real memory of the same thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) Uh-uh... That could promote a partial breakthrough of the real trip. McCLANE (overlapping) Revive him without any false memory implantation and get him out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we just wipe out the memory of his visit here? McCLANE (nodding; relieved) Yes.  Good.  I'll destroy his file and cancel his fee. I have a feeling that the longer he doesn't know who he is, where he's been, where he's going and who we are, the better off we'll all be.  I'm taking a holiday. A real one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves.  The others stare after him, looking very grim

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dazed and disoriented Douglas Quail comes out of an inner door and walks through the lobby towards the exit door. An attractive RECEPTIONIST, her bare breasts visible through a clear plastic blouse, watches him; she then looks toward McClane who has half-opened the door to view Quail's progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail travels down.  Uncomprehendingly, he looks out at the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail stumbles through the fairly crowded foyer, obliviou to anything around him.  A red-headed man may or may not watching him.  He makes a phone call from a pocket phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scene open on Quail, in the back of the cab; he looks around, slowly coming to his senses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travelling south along Third Avenue, passing Fourty-third street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although the driver's voice is a little mechanical (flat in tone) he is filmed from Quail's POV, and it isn't obvious he is anything other than an ordinary cab driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-three thirteen "G" Street, Sector "L", Twin Towers, Apartment six-thirty- five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did I get here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera now cuts to a shot in front of the driver.  He is a fairly human-like robot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don not understand the question, sir or madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did I get into this cab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stepped into it in the normal manner, sir or madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reception area and hallway leading to the elevators i smart and clean, though not lavish.  A uniformed and arme DOORMAN is standing by the entrance door. Filmed from the elevator end of the area, we see the cab pull up and Quail alight and enter the building.  He nods to the doorman and approaches the elevators.  As he reach them a MAN steps out from behind the camera.  A 2ND MAN enters from a door opposite the elevators.  Quail looks at them and becomes quite panicky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you the man from Mars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a modern, lethal gun from his pocket.  Quail tur but the other man is behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give us a reason to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail looks toward the doorman, who is paying little attention to the events.  As the two men edge Quail towar the door, he call out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Zimmer...Mr. Zimmer... help me... they're...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the doorman turns calmly away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men lead Quail past a number of cars to their own vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you taking me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told everyone at Rekall about you trip to Mars. Where you went, who you worked for, what you did --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I didn't... Are you telling me... I did go to Mars?  I don't remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've remembered too much. The Sphinx Project, for a start....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused; remembers only fragments) Sphinx?... No, no, I don't, I... What about the people at Rekall?  I don't recall Rekall but you said if they know what I did?  Why don't you ask them?  They'll tell you I didn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've been taken care of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither man bothers answering.  They arrive at their car and open the door for Quail.  He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What are you going to do with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps Quail hard across the face.  Quail is terrified. He is tearful with fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God!  No!  You're going to kill me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cringes.  His hands across his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's going to kill you if [you do what you're told.] We're visiting E.I.O. for some new tests.  Now get in, or do we start playing rough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  It's not my fault!  You can't do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start to force him into the car physically. Suddenly, Quail stops cringing.  the FEAR DISAPPEARS FROM HIS FACE, and is replaced by an odd, thoughtful expressio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Wait a minute, I remember --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, Quail?  What do you remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Mars... they tried to kill me... And....

dialogues.speaker: QUAIL TRANSFORMS INTO A HIGHLY SKILLED KILLING MACHINE.
dialogues.text: In an instant, he karate-chops both agents across the windpipe, and they crumple to the ground. Quail steps back.  He stares at the two bodies, incredulo then stares at his own deadly HANDS.  It is as though the belong to someone else. Then, leaving the two agents sprawled across the alley, h races back into the basement door of his building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirsten is watching another pornographic video when Quail bursts in.  He is still disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know I've been to Mars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirsten gets up and turns off the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!  This stupid obsess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I think I've been.  I vaguely recall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug, you've got to forget...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Forget?  Remembering is the problem I must've been to one of those artificial memory places...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But something went wrong... something about a real memory... and then those men...  tried to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What men?  Doug, you're crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to mix a drink from a well-stocked cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You're here now.  They didn't kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  That's what's so amazing. I killed them.  I think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirsten stops pouring her drink and look at him sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?  Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail points down with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Doug!  It's something they put into your mind at the memory place.  Fantasies. That's their business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sips her drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You're a computer operator. You're a bore.  You're a wimp.  You're not a killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm involved somehow with E.I.O.  It's true.  It's no fantasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks around the apartment drawing curtains and puttin out the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug, I want you to see a doctor.  Now Alec and Shirley Turnbull have a good man.  He helped Alec through his breakdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For fuck's sake, this is no breakdown!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirsten is taken aback at his use of language.  He stride into the bathroom and slams the door.  She turns on one lamp, goes to a telephone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail takes a washcloth, turns the hot water up full and soaks the cloth under the steaming water.  Using it as a compress, he presses it against his face and his neck, to drain off some of the tension. He turns off the water.  Towelling his head dry, he opens the bathroom door. The instant he does this, a blinding white BURST OF LIGHT comes arcing into the bathroom, and the back wall crinkle and CHARS into a swatch of blackness. QUAIL DIVES OUT THE DOOR, just as ANOTHER BOLT incinerate the spot where he was standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE ROOM IS IN TOTAL DARKNESS.  The only thing visible is the pale rectangle of the balcony window, with the curtai drawn over it. QUAIL and his ASSAILANT cannot be seen -- but they can be HEARD.  There is the sound of a SCUFFLE -- the meaty THUD of a FIST CONNECTING WITH FLESH -- and a painful GRUNT as someone's breath whooshes out. The LIGHT COMES ON.  Quail is standing with one hand on t lamp, and the other twisting KIRSTEN's arm up behind her back.  A pistol lies on the floor.  Quail is totally stun He releases her arm, shoving her away from him, at the sa time scooping up the pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God!  Did you say I need a psychiatrist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) I haven't seen you move that fast since I've known you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (outraged) How could you do it?  After eight years!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not your wife, Quail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not my wife!  You are out of your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indifferent; nursing her arm) It's a false memory implant. I never saw you before six weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is totally disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you lying like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Quail.  It's true.  You work for E.I.O.  So do I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she speaks, she walks to a picture on the wall and fro behind it pulls out a small wallet.  She flips it open to show him her E.I.O. badge.  He looks down uncomprehending at the holographic lettering "Earth Intelligence Organisa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating their surroundings) But why all of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) We had to watchdog you...make sure the erasure took.  A wife seemed like a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I remember it!  All of it!... Us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All implanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our friends... my work... eight years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The job's real -- you've had is six weeks -- since you got back from Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down, holds his hand to his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) It's all a fabrication, Quail. Everything you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is crazy!  If all my memories are false, who am I?  What am I?  Jesus... it's like I don't exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You exist, all right. (very cold) That's the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause as Quail mentally gropes frantically, for what to do next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you try to kill me? Why does E.I.O. want me dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't particularly.  That was my idea.  This assignment was boring me to death.  The personality they gave you wasn't too thrilling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what did I do on Mars that they have to keep me from telling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've no idea.  I just work here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right... I'm leaving. Don't try and follow me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to follow you. You can't get away from E.I.O. Nobody does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail looks at her as if seeing her for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder you got the role as my bitchy wife -- type casting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves.  Kirsten smiles secretively.  She goes to a drawer, opens it and removes a tiny instrument that looks like a TV channel-changer.  There is a very small light on the instrument, which begins flashing on and off, as the instrument  begins to make BEEPING SOUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail walks briskly out onto the street, controlling his paces, trying not to look suspicious.  After a beat, he heads for the nearest subway entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now underground, Quail tries to blend in with the other subway people.  He heads toward the weapons check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OFFICIAL VEHICLE slams to a halt next to the subway entrance and a whole load of INTENSE MEN pours out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail now shuffles along in a lineup of people waiting to get through the WEAPONS CHECK.  He tries to control his nervousness.  He passes.  The guard smiles at him, pleased to see he has remembered his gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the men with guns drawn come pouring down the subway stairs.  The SUBWAY COPS and WEAPONS CHECK are stunned to see four large men brandishing guns push their way throug the weapons check gate without seeming to notice them.  O gunman flashes a HOLOGRAPHIC BADGE ENCASED IN PLASTIC at them. The gunman reach the bottom of the stairs and race closer to the subway train, which is just departing.  The men halt abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second gunman adjusts a small plug - a radio receiver in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't be able to track him again until he comes up above ground!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail sits in the subway car as it barrels through the night, not knowing exactly where he will go.  He is confused, distraught.  A commercial comes onto the video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired?  Exhausted?  Need a vacation?  Don't settle for memories, experience the real thing.  Daily departures on the space shuttle to Mars.  Visit the wonders of....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail emerges from underground and looks around.  The streets are almost deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GUNMEN SIT IN THE OV.  The one with the ear plug [suddenly talks.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming in again.  Loud and clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down at an illuminated street map built into the car's dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab comes into view.  Quail quickly hails it and jumps in.  Cab moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is still pondering what to do next.  He glances out one window, though not at anything in particular.  Sudden the silence is shattered as bullets rip through the windo on the other side.  Quail ducks to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide shot shows that the cab is being fired on by a man leaning from the window of an official patrol vehicle.  H is aiming at the tires and driver, rather than directly a Quail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullets are still pouring in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unemotionally) You are being fired on, sir or madam, please leave the cab at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the floor, Quail pushes the door handle and rolls out onto the street.  The pursuing car occupants fail to notice his exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars continue, as Quail picks himself up from the gutter and moves off down a narrow side street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Please....]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullets rip into the robot driver's neck, severing the head from the body.  The head hits the window then bounce back onto the front seat.  It continues talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...leave the cab as bullets are hitting the vehicle in considerable quantities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi mounts the footpath and smashes through the disp window of a store.  Clothes models are scattered and brok When the noise abates, the severed head of the robot driv is lying among the dummies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This company, sir or madam, will institute legal action for damages...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail emerges from the side street and sees "End of the Line" Hotel.  It is clean, bland, middle class.  He quick crosses the road and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foyer is brightly lit and empty.  Quail approaches th DESK CLERK, who is reading a book.  "Dr. No", marked, in flowing script, "from the classic series".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Help you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing over money) A room for the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly putting down the book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing over money) Here's ten thousand.  Forget the ID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DESK CLERK looks up at him, with interest.  His hand hovers over the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I have a liaison with a lady... and I'm married...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand, sir.  Nothing like a bit on the side, eh? Bit of fugitive flesh.  The greatest aphrodisiac is a new body, wouldn't you say, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail looks at him with distaste but is only anxious to be given the key to his room.  He says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail unlocks the door and enters.  No sooner does he relock the door then THE PHONE RINGS.  He freezes, stares at it for three rings, then picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into receiver) I told you, I don't want to be disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) If you want to live, don't hand up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is stunned.  He says nothing, but doesn't hang up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; filtered) They've got you bugged... They're gonna find you. Faster than you can say "Back Rodgers". (quickly) And don't bother shaking down your clothes -- the monitor is embedded in your skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reeling) Who are you?  What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man telephoning Quail is calling from a bar.  Occasio ally people pass him on their way to the toilets.  He is youngish and conservatively dressed.  He speaks rapidly and urgently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a wet towel and wrap it around your head.  That will deaden the signal.  It'll take longer for them to pinpoint you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I trust you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) There's a real old saying - "Beggars can't be choosers". Go and soak your head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail puts the phone down and rushes to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The earphone wearer and driver are moving in on the signa generated by Quail's bug.  Suddenly, the small illuminate cross on the dashboard map cuts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut the language, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gone!  Some...malfunction...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unscientifically, he prod the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (world-weary air) Toldya the Martian assembled [stuff don't work.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail rushes back into the room with a wet towel, turban-like, wrapped around his head.  He rapidly picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) Head over to Skid Row -- to the Lucky Stub Pawnshop -- corner of Park Avenue and Fifty-eighth.  Tell the man you're Mr. Hotchkiss; you came for your Grecian candlesticks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (infuriated) What do I want with Grecian candlesticks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man on the phone looks around anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just do it!  This is no time for small talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered; not quite convinced) How did you know where to find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been tailing you since you get back from Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're E.I.O.  You're on the other team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) I'm E.I.O.  But I was your best friend.  Scott Stevens - we arranged this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to recall) I can't remember - only bits...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered; overlapping) I was your fail-safe -- if and when the shooting started. Good luck.  Look me up if you remember me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott Stevens hangs up the phone.  He looks around cautiously, then walks a few steps to the mens room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott Stevens walks to the row of troughs and begins to urinate.  The room is empty.  He hears a noise and looks around.  Two EIO men are standing there aiming lethal-loo high-velocity weapons at him.  One of them is the red-hea man we've already seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look at that.  He's really got his hands full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so full, so I've heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still urinating, the frustrated Scott Stevens can only lo back over his shoulder.  Laughing, both men open fire, riddling him with bullets.  He collapses in an undignifie heap, his head in the water at the base of the trough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail, with towel around his head, glances up and down th corridor -- spots a sign that says "FIRE EXIT".  He races towards it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OV slams up in front of the hotel and a carload of MEN tear out of it and barge into the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The startled clerk jumps to his feet as the group of armed men enter rapidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick.  The guy who checked in fifteen minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous) Room...thirty-six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the armed men instantly head off up the stairs, their weapons at the ready.  Clerk watches, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) He was only meeting a lady... Aren't you guys overdoing it a bit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is walking along briskly, still with the towel around his head.  A few passers-by look at him curiously. He puts his hand together and greets them Indian-style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: which reads: "PARK AVENUE / 58TH STREET". PULL BACK to reveal "The Lucky Stub Pawnshop".  WINOS lurk on the corner.  Park Avenue has deteriorated into a slum. QUAIL ENTERS FRAME, and approaching the pawnshop, steppin over a BUM in a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is just entering; an old-fashioned BELL overhead, tripped by the door opening, announces his entrance. At once, an immense FAT MAN emerges from the back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanta camera?  I got some good, top-quality ones.  You want silk rugs?  Handmade last century in Iran...all perfect. You want videos?  Old movies... classics...all those Vietnam war ones...real quaint stuff... you want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting; awkwardly) I'm Hotchkiss...I came for the...Grecian candlesticks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fat Man studies him warily for a long moment; then he disappears through the curtain. In a brief moment, he emerges again, carrying a small, "makeup-sized" case, as well as two large candelabra. The Pawnbroker puts the case on the counter.  Quail looks at the case with curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I wonder if you could tell me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both look around as someone enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust these will look well in you... mosque.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opening up the small case. PULL BACK to reveal they are Quail's hands.  The hotel room he's now in is obviously a different one than the last one we saw him in.  The room is large but run-down, the walls are peeling, the architecture is much older, etc. Quail examines the contents of the case:  there are CREDI CARDS and also MONEY, several stacks of bills, neatly tied -- some of it the conventional green, but most of it red.

dialogues.speaker: RED MONEY
dialogues.text: On the face of it is printed:  "MARS FEDERAL COLONY".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutters) Martian money....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail thumbs through the money, and whistles softly to himself as he sees how much there is. Also in the case are:  TWO PASSPORTS;  a small CASSETTE RECORDER;  a rolled-up LEATHER POUCH and a spray can of some sort;  and a strange thing that looks like a silver mask.  He examines the face mask, studies BLACK LETTERS WRITTEN ACROSS IT (which we are not close enough to read) and then puts it aside.  Another item now catches  his eye:  a wristwatch.  He sees a conspicuous red button on the side of the watch, and PRESSES IT.  INSTANTLY, TO HIS

dialogues.speaker: THIN AIR AND STAND THERE IN THE ROOM A FEW FEET AWAY FROM
dialogues.text: QUAIL:  he's an EXACT HOLOGRAPHIC DUPLICATE of Quail -- down to the clothes Quail is wearing now. The image stands and watches Quail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What the hell...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail smiles, presses the red button again.  There is a HUMMING SOUND -- and the man FADES INTO THIN AIR -- like a television set being turned off. Quail looks bemused. Now he unrolls the leather pouch and looks inside.  There he finds what look like SURGICAL INSTRUMENTS;  a sponge, a long piece of wire doubled over, with some attachments and a tiny METAL HEAD on one end, and some tubes of salve He turns on the cassette recorder. The VOICE he hears on the cassette TAPE is HIS OWN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quail's voice) "Hauser, this is Hauser -- or whatever you think your name is now.  If you're listening to this, I'm talking to myself. Your memory's been erased and you've got a wet towel around your head. (he does) "The first thing you've got to do is get rid of that bug in your head."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of the tape continues as Quail follows instructions - pushing the wire up into a bloody portion of his neck, just below the ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monitoring device is located in your left maxillary sinus cavity.  Make a small incision in your neck just below the left ear, and insert the wire up into the sinus.  The head is self-guiding.  Just shove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You won't feel a thing.  The spray cartridge contains a local anesthetic and a blood coagulant.  Careful, it's my neck, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding the wet towel against his neck, Quail slowly withdraws the wire.  On the end of it is a tiny, metal bead, the Transmitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man with the ear plug suddenly reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's come on again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 1st man quickly check the map-grid in the dashboard. A small bright 'x' is flashing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in that old flophouse. Plaza Hotel.  Central Park South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is anxious to get rid of the transmitter.  He looks around and notices a rat trap near a rat hole in the skirting board. He carefully - avoiding springing the trap - removes the piece of cheese and pushes the transmitter inside.  He then throws the cheese into the rat hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is moving swiftly through the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, he's really moving around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CU of the screen shows the small 'x' moving in circles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up.  Another follows it.  Armed men leap out from both.  The EARPLUG WEARER indicates they should go down an alley at the side of a service door.  They advance cautiously, guns at the ready.  They see no one. The EARPLUG WEARER indicates another, even narrower, alle leading off to one side.  Two of the men sneak cautiously up to it, their guns at the ready. A large rat scurries out from behind overfull garbage bins.  Furious, they fire.  The bullets rip the bins to shreds, scattering refuse everywhere.  The rat is killed. They all stare in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya dirty rat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPENING CLOSE on a MONITOR SCREEN slated "HAUSER/QUAIL" followed by a serial number and some dates.  The slate vanishes, replaced by a scene of Quail -- undergoing some KIND OF MILITARY TRAINING. PAN to OTHER MONITORS, all depicting Quail in other action scenes -- on some kind of mission, driving a car, etc. TECHNICIANS man the monitors, scrolling through them in fast-forward and fast reverse as if searching files. The technicians turn as Cohaagen and his aides enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (demands) Anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're running every one of his memory tapes for the past fifteen years.  Nothing yet, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be something -- some place he would go, some friend he would run to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red-haired E.I.O. man joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cohaagen; quietly) They lost him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red-headed man nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Are you sure the original suppression took?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely, sir.  He thinks he's Quail, a computer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Then how do you explain what he's doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just his instincts.  He was well trained by E.I.O.... Maybe the memory cap's fractured. Portions of his prior identity could be leaking through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very anxious) He'll remember Mars?  The Sphinx Project?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fragments.  Nothing more. Nothing he could piece together. I did advise terminating him, rather than implanting an identify alternative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think I am?  A barbarian?  We're not living in the twentieth century!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the video screen again.  An image has flashed onto it of an attractive Eurasian girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hold it there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies the picture, which changes to show the same girl from different angles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers are boarding a COMMERCIAL SPACECRAFT.  In addition to the STEWARDESSES checking their tickets, ther are two PLAINCLOTHES MEN checking every passenger.  They carry some kind of small, portable ELECTRONIC DEVICE that they shine in the face of each passenger going through. (It gives off a BLUE BEAM and HUMS.) The passengers are a diverse group - businessmen, officia government people, etc.  There is also a large tour group consisting of a predominately middle-aged and determinedl jolly crowd, many of them carrying duty-free bags.  They are being marshaled by an harassed TOUR ORGANIZER, who is carrying aloft a hand-painted sign... "MARTIAN TOUR GROUP The last of the passengers board the spacecraft.  The chief PLAINCLOTHES MAN nods to an official and the door begins to close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he had to travel to Mars with that bunch, I'd be sorry for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We couldn't have missed him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way.  Let's get a coffee before the next shuttle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the PASSENGERS -- a middle-aged WOMAN - unbuckles her seat belt and heads for the restroom, carrying her handbag, and some clothes on a hanger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman locks the door and turns to the mirror.  She opens her bag, takes out a spray container, SPRAYS HER FACE with it, and takes out -- the SILVER FACE MASK we saw in Quail's emergency kit. She holds the mask to her face.  There is a SIZZLING NOISE, and SMOKE rises from behind the mask. She lowers the mask.  Her face is now that of QUAIL. He tears up a passport and drops it down a chute. He reaches inside his dress, starts to REMOVE his "FALSIE

dialogues.speaker: MASK
dialogues.text: We can read the BLACK LETTERING written across it now: "LASER FACIAL".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail exits from the lavatory and glances toward the ebullient tour crowd.  He turns and looks in the other direction and sees a video theater advertising "ROCKY 36" with Sylvester Stallone III, Jnr.  He isn't too excited, but heads towards it.  He pauses a little when an announcement comes over the intercom. A LITTLE BELL sounds, followed by INTERCOM STATIC.  Quail looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, if you'll glance out the starboard viewports, you'll behold an indeed awesome sight --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail goes to a viewport and PEERS, transfixed.  He is seeing... at last... the object of his obsession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SPACELINER -- which we have deliberately not seen bef this moment for dramatic effect -- banks and turns, sudde bringing into view -- MARS. AN IMMENSE ORANGE GLOBE -- so close it looks like it's going to fall on us.  It dwarfs the spaceliner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those long gorges you see, clearly are the legendary canals of Mars....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The liner drops toward the surface of Mars.  Below:  a NETWORK OF INTERSECTING LINES crisscross the planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Of course, they are not manmade canals, but vast natural chasms ...many deeper and larger than the Grand Canyon.  Though utterly without moisture now, scientists have determined that they were formed by massive flooding millions of years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail stares, his brow furrowing as if with some deep hidden memory he can't quite recall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Surface temperatures at the Martian equator is minus one-hundred and twenty degrees  Centigrade -- in winter. Fortunately, this time of year it's slightly more seasonable: Sixty degrees, Fahrenheit, outside the domes. (beat) Please remember, folks, that outside the domes you'll need to carry your own personal oxygen supply at all times. The atmosphere of Mars is almost a vacuum.  Thank you for flying with Interstellar and we hope your stay will be a pleasant one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA follows the spaceliner until the ENTIRE FRAME is filled with the RED-ORANGE sands of MARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An endless expanse of boulder-studded red sand, under a red-orange sky. The desert is cut by a ROAD, which snakes across the rocky terrain.  Some surface TRAFFIC moves along the road (all pressurized vehicles since the atmosphere of Mars is almost a pure vacuum) - including the MARSPORT BUS.

dialogues.speaker: A CITY UNDER A DOME.
dialogues.text: In the midst of the stark, trackless landscape -- it's midday, scorching -- rises a huge weatherbeaten GEODESIC STRUCTURE, its glass surface scarred by sandstorm damage. Its feeling is like an old Western, when Clint Eastwood rides into Tombstone -- the raw, forbidding vistas, with a tough town carved out of the wilderness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is looking out at the desolate landscape.  The TOUR ORGANISER, an amiable middle-aged man sits beside him. It is possible he is not a married man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no Garden of Eden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Quite a bit to see, though. The canyons, the old Sphinx...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much, really.  Millions of years old.  Bit like the one that used to be in Egypt, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Got destroyed in the Arab wars... What about this independence movement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissive) Not worth worrying about. Mostly descendants of the original colonists from Earth. Now they want self-rule so they can sell us all the minerals... I don't think we've met.  You with our group?  Takes me a while to know everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Douglas Quail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard Toltz. (they shake hands) Well, Doug, I hope we'll see a lot more of each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulls up outside a modern tourist hotel.  The buildings surrounding it have a much more improvised, temporary look.  Most are pre-fabricated structures. The streets are crowded and there is a "frontier-town" atmosphere.  Stalls sell fruit and vegetables, also water and air containers. A lot of greenery is evident - this is to absorb CO2 and emit oxygen, thus helping with the air supply under the dome. Some small, ragged boys look at QUAIL as he looks around before going inside the hotel.  Suddenly, one of them thr a small sack at him.  It hits his chest and leaves a yell stain.  The hotel DOORMAN chases the boys away....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smogpsucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the other side of the street, a gang of URCHINS with a harmonica start singing some kind of defiant PATRIOTIC SONG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how it is, sir.  Some of these red-asses are a bit prejudiced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prejudiced?  Against what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earthmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street song has swelled, adult MINERS and CITIZENS joining the belligerent chorus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they singing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Martian National Anthem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail tips the doorman, enter the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail passes several kiosks -- a magazine stand, currency exchange, clothing store, shoeshine stand.  A SHOESHINE BOY looks up at Quail. Quail walks past, enters the main lobby.  The atrium entryway is absolutely fabulous; a complete contrast to t dirty, Casbah-like streets.  AFFLUENT-LOOKING PEOPLE in spotless linen fill the lobby. Quail stops to examine a large ROTATING DISPLAY sitting o a table in the middle of the lobby.  It is a stand-up mod of a SPHINX.  Across the top is written "THE FIRST WONDER OF MARS".  A recorded VOICE repeats a canned speech --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...the Martian Sphinx... only evidence of non-human civilization ever discovered ...age estimated at over eighteen million years...

dialogues.speaker: SHOESHINE BOY
dialogues.text: He stares at Quail.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Quail approaches the Registration Desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to have you back with us, Mr. Hauser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is startled to be recognized -- particularly by this name.  He tries to stay casual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to be back. (pick up pen) I'm flattered you remember me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part of my job, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts to sign; hesitates) Do you remember my first name, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles.  Charles Hauser, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm impressed. (now he signs) Listen.  I need transportation to the... uh... the Sphinx. Can you arrange it for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir.  But Earth government has sealed off the excavation site completely. No one but survey teams and archaeologists are allowed closer than twenty miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clerk taps a few keys on a computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... (spots something on the computer) Do you want the item you left with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What item?  Oh... yes, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clerk turns to the safe, retrieves an envelope. He hands it -- and an ELECTRONIC ROOM KEY -- to Quail.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH BINOCULARS
dialogues.text: Far in the distance, a dusty red structure squats amid barren dunes.  We see vehicles, scaffolding, a fortified perimeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail stands at the window, looking through binoculars. He lowers them irritably, tosses them on the bed. Quail tugs the envelope from his pocket, tears it open. Inside is a single slip of paper, on which is written in longhand:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last Chance Air Station Kilometer 61   Gird Square T9"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is now sunset on Mars and it's literally of inearthly beauty.  The sun is bold and blood red;  the foggy, drip- ping glass of the Dome tints the light into strange color Quail emerges from the hotel, properly attired now in a white tropical suit, and starts for the taxi stand. Behind him, also emerging from the hotel, is the Shoeshin Boy.  He keeps out of sight -- but is definitely tailing Quail. As Quail nears the first solar-powered taxi in line, he i approached by an amiable-looking CALYPSO GUY wearing a We Indian shirt and bright straw hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need a cab, boss mon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail hesitates, unsure of the protocol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Mine's right around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating first cab in line) That one's closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I out-hustle him, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO CABBIES exchange curses as Quail, wary, follows the Calypso Guy around a corner, climbs into the small solar car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An AIR LOCK whooshes open underneath a Checker Cab sign. Bennie and Quail emerge in the solar-powered car -- set off into the desert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi traverses the same type desert that Quail crosse a few hours ago.  Only now is looks completely different. The late light tints everything in pastel shades, Quail i awed by the grandeur of the Lawrence-of-Arabia-like setti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail and Bennie's taxi approaches a brightly-lit oasis i the middle of the desert.  There's a cafe, repair facilit and a huge parking lot -- all under a garish neon sign:

dialogues.speaker: "LAST CHANCE AIR STATION AND ASLOON
dialogues.text: Quail and Bennie's taxi pulls in and parks.  In the lot i a collection of strange and colorful vehicles:  huge ore trucks that pull eight trailers, mountain prospecting jee Grapes-of-Wrath jalopies.  Quail and Bennie disembark, we ing breathing masks, and enter the main building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The joint is a combination saloon/cathouse/casino.  There are slot machines, HOOKERS, MINERS and HOMESTEADERS; it i like a Nevada brothel -- packed with wild and woolly indi vidualists, the equivalent of Old West trappers, prospect and cowboys -- but with a space-age look. Quail and Bennie elbow their way to the bar.  Fragments o conversation are overheard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...if that intergalactic little Napoleon thinks I'm sellin' and clearin' outta here, he can think again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a laugh) ...watcha gonna do when he cuts off the air, Luke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you'll be breathin' red dust and shittin' bricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennie and Quail pass another group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...my wife ain't goin' on one of those space shuttles... she hates flyin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...aw, come on... flyin's safer'n crossin' the road...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...yeah, there ain't been a real disaster since that collision off Phobos, nigh on twenty years ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) ...well, that killed twelve thousand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, Bennie... Tombstone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorta.  Bunch of miners out here got their own claims, from way back.  Cohaagen's buyin' em all up, says he's gonna cut off the air an' water if they won't sell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail attracts the attention of the BARTENDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Melina Noel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've found her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His nod indicates an area behind Quail.  He turns to see an attractive waitress placing drinks on tables.  She doesn't notice Quail.  He walks toward her through the crowd.  Bennie watches, then tactfully slips away. MELINA turns to return to the bar and runs straight into Quail.  She stops, obviously astonished to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost in tears, she pushes her way through the crowd to billiard room, which is separated from the main bar by swinging doors. There are no occupants and it is almost in darkness.  Qua bewildered, follows her.  Inside the billiard room he tur on the lights which illuminates the area of the table. (NOTE:  As Quail and Melina speak, the activity in the outside bar can be seen above the swinging doors.) Melina is still fighting back tears.  Quail stops in fron of her, unsure about what to do.  He has no recollection of how well he might have known this woman. Suddenly, she slaps him hard across the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) You bastard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rubs his painful cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) That's new -- the innocent look. (bitter sarcasm) You didn't have that one before. (beat) Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh... I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll say it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks relieved (but tries to cover).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't worry.  I got the note. You discharged your obligation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What note?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the usual one.  "Must return immediately to Earth... the wife needs me..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a wife.  Well, I do - but not a real wife. (getting desperate) Hell... look... someone else sent that note.  Someone who --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you here for?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you!  I don't even know why --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melina bursts into tears.  Quail rather tentatively puts his arms around her.  She welcomes this at first, but the pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Whoever I was, I must have been a helluva guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Whoever you were"???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen.  I've for to tell  you something.  I beg you to believe me... help me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All Melina's suspicions come rushing back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Something happened to my mind. Memory suppression, false implant, I don't know what --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melina backs off.  Quail grows more desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What I'm saying is... I don't remember you.  I don't remember us.  I don't remember me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melina's expression grows dead hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [And I thought...]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring the question) Memory erasure is what they use on agents.  Go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait... I was an agent -- I'm not now -- just tell me who I am!  How did we know each other?  Why are they trying to kill me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a step toward her, nearly frantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not trusting you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You loved me once, you must have --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you was a liar.  Who you are now I don't even know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Melina --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tears starting) Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your help --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying quietly) Get out!  Get the hell away from me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail gives up; goes through the doors and leaves.  Melin slumps her shoulder against the table and cries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail enters from the cafe.  Bennie is kneeling beside hi taxi, repairing a tire.  He look up, sees Quail approach. On his right hand, Bennie has a mechanical device capable of spinning 360 degrees.  He uses it to twirl a lug nut tight on his tire.  As Quail approaches, Bennie removes the TOOL ATTACHMENT from his HAND, tosses it into a kit beside the taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't look so good, boss. All over the Universe, women is an awful curse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door for Quail, beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail still broods, Bennie tries to cheer him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a tough planet, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some guy really screwed her - screwed her up real good. Some Earthman.  Just hopped on a space shuttle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennie bright tone isn't improving Quail's mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Bennie.  You're pretty well informed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that means I know it all, you're right, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about the Sphinx?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know nothin'.  Not about the Sphinx.  That's out of the ball park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to get there.  Can't you help me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No can do, mon.  You want women, cigarettes, red-market money, booze, even air or water... Bennie's your man. But the Sphinx... that's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The solar car is moving through the crowd, when suddenly SIRENS approach on a cross street.  Bennie brakes and sto He and Quail watch as POLICE MOTORCYCLES clear a path for huge, GAS-POWERED LIMO.  MINERS on the sidewalks shout

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... look at that one, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big cheese in town.  Big smelly cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohaagen?  But isn't he often here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way.  That cat just cheat the Martian workers without ever leavin' his place in Beverly Hills.  Somethin' must be cookin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail keeps his face in shadow and watches Cohaagen with curiosity as he passes.  Cohaagen is lit up briefly by a street lamp.  His face makes an impression on Quail, who perhaps faintly remembers him in the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quail enters, turns on the lights, locks the door.  He checks all the rooms.  Then he crosses to the dresser, studies himself in the mirror.  He looks haggard. Quail opens a drawer, takes out his "emergency case," set it on top and opens it.  He removes a shoulder holster an pistol, sets them aside.  He takes out a tape recorder. He sets the recorder down gingerly, as if somewhere in there were contained the answers to all his questions. He's just about to activate it, when he hears a KNOCK at the door. Quail freezes.  Another KNOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through door) Mr. Hauser...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hauser, I want to talk to you... about Douglas Quail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
